item.title: Ocean currents respond to climate change in unexpected ways
item.description: As the planet warms and winds strengthen, the poleward flow of tropical waters is predicted to also intensify. But observations tell a different story.

item.title: Classical precursor to turbulence observed in a superfluid
item.description: An obstacle dragged through a Bose–Einstein condensate can leave a well-known pattern of vortices in its wake.

item.title: Erratic helium prices create research havoc
item.description: Researchers report forgoing salaries and taking on fewer graduate students to cope with volatile prices for liquid helium.

item.title: With Trump in charge, uncharted waters lie ahead for science
item.description: Now that Congress and the White House are firmly in Republican control, President-elect Trump has a clear path to enact his science policy, when it emerges.

item.title: The unfolding and control of network cascades
item.description: The same connections that give a network its functionality can promote the spread of failures and innovations that would otherwise remain confined.

item.description: In some ways, the hit TV show reinforces popular stereotypes about scientists. In others, notably in its affectionate portrayals, it plays against type.

item.title: Carl-Gustaf Rossby: Theorist, institution builder, bon vivant
item.description: Best known for discovering the planetary waves that now bear his name, the Swede was arguably the most influential and innovative meteorologist of the 20th century.

item.description: Unlike a rubber balloon, a kamifusen has a hole left open to the surrounding air. So why doesn’t it collapse when you bat it around?

item.description: A “stop-motion” crystallization experiment laid bare the liquid’s behavior in a temperature range that was once considered inaccessible.

item.description: A structure made entirely out of an n-type semiconductor can mimic some properties of a p-type semiconductor.

item.description: Although still productive, the facilities must find alternative funding to avoid being sacrificed for new cutting-edge telescopes.

item.title: Citizen observers chart Arctic change
item.description: Researchers are increasingly partnering with local residents to obtain climate and environmental data. But the endeavor calls for interpersonal savvy.

item.title: Effort in asteroid defense under way despite funding constraints
item.description: A US interagency program is refining methods of deflecting asteroids as it works toward finding tens of thousands of undetected near-Earth objects.

item.title: High-energy-density science blooms at NIF
item.description: The weapons facility is exploring phenomena found in brown dwarfs, the cores of “super Earths,” new phases of carbon, and other extreme environments.

item.title: How did a scientific Siberia turn into AstroBoulder?
item.description: Boulder, Colorado, grew to become an important science center in part because nearby mountains provided an excellent spot for solar observation. But local scientists’ connections to the Northeast establishment and some clever PR didn’t hurt.

item.title: In referees we trust?
item.description: The imprimatur bestowed by peer review has a history that is both shorter and more complex than many scientists realize.

item.title: A bridge between undergraduate and doctoral degrees
item.description: Initiated in 2013, the American Physical Society Bridge Program has assisted more than a hundred underrepresented racial and ethnic minority students to pursue PhDs in physics.

item.description: With a few simple instructions, participants at the Atlanta Science Festival mimicked a phenomenon that can have fatal consequences in biological systems.

item.description: Researchers harnessed nanoconfinement effects to achieve elasticity and efficient charge transport in a semiconducting material.

item.title: Electron diffraction sees hydrogen atoms
item.description: The detection of the small, light atoms heralds the emergence of the technique as a powerful crystallographic tool.

item.title: Circuitry made robust enough for Venus
item.description: Silicon carbide devices lasted more than three weeks in a laboratory simulation of the corrosive conditions that prevail on the planet’s surface.

item.description: The most immediate concern is that the country remain attractive and welcoming for foreign researchers and students.

item.title: Can a trusting relationship between DOE and its labs be restored?
item.description: Experiments to scale back micromanagement are under way at two national laboratories. Other lab contractors also report measured improvements.

item.title: Climate-data rescue efforts gear up
item.description: Data disappearing is far from the only thing researchers are worried about under the Trump administration, but it’s one they can do something about.

item.title: Our changing view of Mars
item.description: The orbiters, landers, and rovers that have probed the red planet over the past two decades reveal it to be chemically complex, historically watery, and suitable as a home for life.

item.title: The laws of life
item.description: Notwithstanding the awe-inspiring diversity of living creatures, the forms and processes of life are limited by universal principles that act at large and small scales.

item.title: Where are they?
item.description: The search for extraterrestrial life is increasingly informed by our knowledge of exoplanets. Within three decades, we may know whether extrasolar life is rare.

item.description: A very ordinary, isolated star varies by 20% in brightness on time scales from a day to a century. No one has yet proposed a convincing explanation.

item.description: A snippet of data has important implications for figuring out the moon’s structure.

item.description: Forming new modes of university leadership using off-campus facilities is essential to sustain the field.

item.description: Combining the principles of interferometry, holography, and microscopy, quantitative phase imaging has emerged as a unique tool for live-cell and tissue imaging.

item.description: Spectacular bursts of particles that seem to appear out of nowhere may shed light on some of nature’s most profound mysteries.

item.description: Whether long-range magnetic order could survive in the 2D limit was an open and fundamental question. The answer is that it can, but it has some surprises in store.

item.title: Coral isotopes track the rise of anthropogenic nitrogen
item.description: Coal use in China has jumped sharply over the past 15 years. The concomitant nitrogen oxide emissions have left their subtle mark on a remote island.

item.title: Proton–proton collisions prove stranger than expected
item.description: Enhanced production of strange particles joins a growing body of evidence that has physicists reevaluating their assumptions about quark–gluon plasmas.

item.description: Radio observatories are accumulating data to detect mergers of supermassive black holes.

item.description: Despite billions of dollars spent preparing to treat and stabilize liquid radioactive wastes, cleaning out leaking tanks at the former nuclear production site in Hanford, Washington, will take decades more.

item.title: As student labor movements grow, scientists turn activist
item.description: A 2016 federal ruling gave graduate assistants the right to unionize. Now students on both sides of the issue are mobilizing.

item.title: Grim news for science and research in Trump budget
item.description: Across-the-board cuts to civilian R&D programs would help pay for increased defense spending, but they face an uncertain future in Congress.

item.description: The spin Hall effect and its companion, the inverse spin galvanic effect, have evolved from topics of academic interest to efficient means for fabricating microelectronic magnetic memories.

item.description: With their hyperfine states serving as two-level qubits, atoms can be packed into closely spaced, laser-cooled arrays and be individually addressed using laser pulses.

item.title: Clippers, yachts, and the false promise of the wave line
item.description: John Scott Russell’s 19th-century theory of ship design promised speed and delivered elegance. But, ultimately, it didn’t hold water.

item.description: Perceiving pitch differences requires the brain to process complex sounds. Remarkably, three-month-old infants with immature brains can hear a wrong note in the children’s song “Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star.”

item.description: Although the craters likely formed about 12 000 years ago, methane is still leaking profusely around and between them.

item.description: Over the past several decades, solar physicists have made steady progress in answering the two long-standing questions, but puzzles remain.

item.description: In applying their research to wartime problems, US physicists changed the relationship between physics, the military, and the government.

item.description: The first medical device to restore a human sense, a cochlear implant converts sound into a train of current pulses that directly stimulate the auditory nerve of a profoundly deaf ear.

item.subdept: They may not be out there
item.title: They may not be out there
Calling computers names in Swedish
Calling computers names in Swedish
Correction
Ancient clues help quantify modern methane
item.description: Natural geological emissions contributed little to the methane levels of the ancient atmosphere. The same could be true today.

item.title: Acoustic levitation widens the study of droplet jetting
item.description: To investigate the fission of charged droplets, a pair of chemists holds one stationary in electrified midair.

item.title: Ships cause their own stormy seas
item.description: Increased lightning frequency over maritime trade routes links pollution to the development of thunderclouds.

item.title: Conduction electrons flow like honey
Now you see this nanoplasmonic mirror. Now you don’t.
Evaluating the habitability of exomoons
Healing defects in perovskite films
Salaries for female physics faculty trail those for male colleagues
item.description: Gender pay gap is tangled with many aspects of physics culture.

item.title: Refracturing may not be all it’s cracked up to be
item.description: Restimulating oil and gas wells that have been fracked will be worthwhile in some cases, but not all.

item.title: The relentless pursuit of hypersonic flight
item.description: How much new science will it take to design a vehicle that can routinely fly at many times the speed of sound?

item.title: Preparing physics students for 21st-century careers
item.description: Whether they end up in industrial, governmental, business, or academic settings, college graduates need plenty of skills beyond an ability to solve problem sets.

item.title: In celebration of Ilya Lifshitz
item.description: This year marks the centenary of the birth of Ilya Mikhailovich Lifshitz, who helped found the field of fermiology and made important contributions to condensed-matter physics and biophysics.

item.title: A Fortunate Universe: Life in a Finely Tuned Cosmos
An Introduction to Complex Systems: Society, Ecology, and Nonlinear Dynamics
Anomaly! Collider Physics and the Quest for New Phenomena at Fermilab
Astrophysics for People in a Hurry
New books
Focus on lasers, imaging, and photonics
Karl-Heinz Rieder
Sheldon Schultz
Da Vinci’s observations of soaring birds
Ship tracks
What do they think we know?
Commentary: The promise of polymers
Trapping molecules for quantum chemistry

item.subdept: Heisenberg letters show courage in horrific times
item.title: Heisenberg letters show courage in horrific times

item.subdept: Heisenberg letters show courage in horrific times
item.title: Heisenberg letters show courage in horrific times
A universal human constant?
Correction
Weiss, Barish, and Thorne share 2017 Nobel Prize in Physics
item.description: Three architects of LIGO are honored for their successful effort to directly detect gravitational waves.

item.title: Two kinds of waves from a neutron-star smashup
item.description: Gravitational and electromagnetic radiation expose a merger that triggered a gamma-ray burst and manufactured heavy elements.

item.title: Cryoelectron microscopy pioneers win chemistry Nobel
item.description: Proteins frozen in vitreous ice are now being imaged with atomic resolution.

item.title: Cruising the seas on the wreckage of a natural disaster
Fluid dynamics explains ancient organism behavior
NASA sees a future with nuclear power
item.description: The space agency views reactors as options both for propulsion to Mars and as a power source for life on the red planet.

item.title: A spray-on material can retrofit walls to save lives in earthquakes
item.description: The cement-based layer can be applied to nonstructural masonry walls to make them bend rather than break.

item.title: Baryon acoustic oscillations: A cosmological ruler
item.description: A density pattern created by acoustic waves in the early universe can be seen in the distribution of galaxies and used as a standard ruler with which to measure cosmological expansion.

item.title: Boosting solar energy conversion with nanofluids
item.description: Suspensions of metallic nanoparticles can harvest valuable heat from sunlight that would otherwise go to waste in a photovoltaic cell.

item.title: Discovering Earth’s radiation belts
item.description: Six decades after the belts’ discovery in 1958, scientists are still finding mysterious features.

item.title: Ripples in Spacetime: Einstein, Gravitational Waves, and the Future of Astronomy
Gravity’s Kiss: The Detection of Gravitational Waves
Introduction to Modern Magnetohydrodynamics
Focus on software and data acquisition
Ronald William Prest Drever
Peter Mansfield
Trigonometry for the heavens
item.description: The stars and planets move not on a flat surface but on the celestial sphere. So ordinary plane trigonometry isn’t adequate to describe their motion.
